tension.dominant_assumption: Performance optimization in collaborative systems is primarily a technical infrastructure problem solvable through better algorithms and architecture.
tension.blind_spot: The role of human coordination patterns and social dynamics in shaping perceived latency and collaboration quality.
tension.core_gap: We lack a conceptual framework that integrates sociotechnical factors into the understanding of 'real-time' in collaborative editing.

expected_output.research_position: Current approaches to collaborative editing latency treat it as a purely technical problem, overlooking how human coordination dynamics shape perceived real-time performance and leaving sociotechnical factors unintegrated.

tension.dominant_assumption: Academic identity development follows a relatively uniform trajectory that can be supported through standard institutional interventions.
tension.blind_spot: The epistemic labour first-generation students perform in translating between home and academic knowledge systems.
tension.core_gap: There is insufficient understanding of how first-generation students construct academic identities at the intersection of cultural, class-based, and institutional discourses.

expected_output.research_position: Little is understood about how first-generation college students negotiate academic identity across cultural and class-based knowledge systems, particularly the epistemic labour of translation that institutional support models fail to recognise.

tension.dominant_assumption: AI literacy can be adequately assessed using competency-based frameworks adapted from digital or computational literacy.
tension.blind_spot: The ethical and epistemic dimensions of AI literacy â€” understanding not just how AI works, but what it means for knowledge and agency.
tension.core_gap: No existing evaluation framework captures both the technical and critical-reflective dimensions of AI literacy in developmentally appropriate ways for K-12 learners.

expected_output.research_position: A new evaluative framework is needed to capture both the technical and critical-reflective dimensions of AI literacy in K-12 education, given that current competency-based models neglect the epistemic and ethical implications of AI.
